description: Argument wiring diagram for sprint-review.tex: the retrospective's claim structure. Central thesis: iterative protocol outperforms single-shot AI on research math, with systematic failures on NO-answer problems due to YES bias + domain-depth gap. The frontier is epistemic (falsification depth), not computational.

nodes.body_text: Sprint data: 341 commits, 55 hours, 3 agents (Joe/Claude/Codex), 10 research-level problems from First Proof (Kolda et al.).
Ground truth: official solutions released Feb 14, 2026, by the problem authors. 68-page document with human solutions and AI commentary.
Scorecard: 6 correct, 2 correct-direction (incomplete proof), 2 wrong. Both wrong answers are on problems where official answer is NO.
Infrastructure: wiring diagrams with typed edges, Codex verification prompts generated per node, reviewer/responder cycle, numerical stress testing. Generation/verification ratio ~1:16.
Key methodological choices: outcome typing (Close/Reduce/Map), layer-switching pattern, PSR/PUR discipline (proposed), wiring-diagram verification.
Tier A (P2, P8, P9, P10): clean matches. Correct answer, sound proof. P9 uses genuinely different construction (degree-3 vs degree-5). P10 praised by official author.
Tier B (P3, P4, P5, P6): right direction, incomplete proof. P3: possible problem substitution. P4: missing hyperbolic Hessian bridge. P6: missing modified barrier. P5: sketch not full rigor.
Tier C (P1, P7): wrong answer. P1: false-premise trap (assumed Phi^4_3 ~ GFF). P7: conditional-to-closure gap (Novikov conjecture blocks manifold upgrade).
Success pattern: structural decomposition. P8's symplectic direct sum, P9's rank-2 bilinear form â€” single structural insight unlocks entire proof.
Success pattern: computational verification as proof guidance. P4's 8000+ trials, P6's 731+ runs. Numerical evidence guides strategy, doesn't replace proof.
Success pattern: cycle methodology. Explore -> attempt -> fail -> characterize failure as theorem -> redirect. P4's SOS infeasibility theorem (7 scripts) eliminated entire strategy class.
Claim: iterative protocol outperforms single-shot AI baselines. 6/10 correct vs AI baselines that got ~1-2 essentially correct. Differentiator is iteration, error correction, and strategic pivots.

Failure pattern: YES bias. Both wrong answers (P1, P7) are NO problems. Constructive arguments easier to generate; obstruction arguments require deep structural theorems. LLMs may be systematically biased toward YES.
Failure pattern: false-premise trap (P1). Assumed Phi^4_3 ~ GFF (false), then correctly deduced quasi-invariance. Logically sound, mathematically wrong. Invisible to internal consistency checks.

Failure pattern: conditional-to-closure gap (P7). Correctly identified all machinery (Fowler, surgery, assembly maps) but resolved conditional step optimistically. Novikov conjecture provides definitive obstruction we didn't test for.

Structural observation: domain depth vs structural reasoning. Failures require deep specialized knowledge (regularity structures, L-theory). Successes admit algebraic/computational verification. Human-AI team strongest on structural reasoning, weakest on domain depth.

P4 near miss: endpoint fixation + query mismatch. We repeatedly ended at Cauchy-Schwarz but worked at wrong mathematical level for the middle step. Searched free-Stam/de Bruijn language, not hyperbolic-Hessian contraction keywords.

P6 near miss: same pattern as P4. Endpoint fixation (average-to-existence transfer) + object inertia (stayed in full-spectrum barrier space). Official proof changes the barrier itself (top-sigma eigenvalues).

Coaching beats dispatching (P6 case study). 'Close the gap in Section 5' generates TryHarder cycle. 'What kind of problem is this?' generates layer switch. 15-minute reframing vs 8-hour persistence. But: coaching did NOT solve the full problem.

Negative knowledge transfer: dead-end theorems are as valuable as successes. P4's SOS infeasibility, P6's technique exhaustion, P7's five hypothetical architectures. Failed proof attempts should produce structured records of WHY they failed.
Threat: non-blinded evaluation. Same team classifies outcomes. Can inflate 'direction-correct' judgments unless tied to explicit criteria.

Threat: baseline comparability. Comparison with single-shot AI is informative but not controlled. 55 hours + iteration + tools + human coaching vs single prompt. Claims should be 'different protocol, better outcomes' not strict model ranking.

Threat: attribution uncertainty. Sprint does not isolate causal contribution of human operator vs protocol itself. Several interventions (routing, stagnation detection, reframing) are plausible automation targets.
Batch 2 protocol: mandatory falsification. For every problem, spend at least one full cycle attempting to prove the opposite answer before committing.
Batch 2 protocol: domain-depth audit. Identify problems requiring deep specialized knowledge early, allocate extra literature mining and adversarial testing.

Batch 2 protocol: state-variable hop. When the same terminal inequality recurs but closure stalls, force deliberate 'state-variable hop' cycle (new potential/barrier definitions) before sharpening constants within old variable.

The epistemic weakness: inability to recognize when a plausible constructive argument is built on a false foundation. Invisible to internal consistency checks. Only domain knowledge reveals the error.

THESIS: The frontier of AI-assisted mathematics is defined by the depth of domain knowledge brought to bear on falsification, not by computational power or reasoning ability. Path forward: better integration with domain-specific knowledge bases + systematic adversarial testing.

edges.evidence: Sprint artifacts (341 commits) compared against official solutions to produce scorecard
Official solutions provide ground truth for scoring
Infrastructure (wiring diagrams, verification prompts, reviewer cycle) enables the iterative protocol that differentiates us from baselines
Outcome typing and layer-switching pattern underpin the cycle methodology
Scorecard decomposed into three tiers by match quality
Scorecard decomposed into three tiers by match quality
Scorecard decomposed into three tiers by match quality
P8 (symplectic direct sum) and P9 (rank-2 bilinear) exemplify structural decomposition wins
P4 (8000+ trials) and P6 (731+ runs) exemplify computational verification as proof guidance
P4's 4-cycle trajectory (explore -> SOS fail -> characterize -> resultant elimination) exemplifies cycle methodology
4 clean matches (P2, P8, P9, P10) vs AI baselines that got ~1-2 essentially correct
Partial results on P4 and P6 exceed single-shot AI baselines (P6: ChatGPT couldn't answer; P4: AI attempt 'did not make sense')
Both wrong answers are NO problems; we defaulted to constructive YES arguments without testing for obstructions
P1 exemplifies false-premise trap: assumed Phi^4_3 ~ GFF, correctly deduced quasi-invariance from false foundation
P7 exemplifies conditional-to-closure gap: identified all machinery but resolved conditional step optimistically
YES bias correlates with domain depth: NO answers require deep obstruction theorems from specialized subfields
P1 requires regularity structures expertise to detect the false premise
P7 requires L-theory/Novikov conjecture expertise to detect the definitive obstruction
P4 near miss: had Cauchy-Schwarz endpoint, n=3 closure, n=4 certification, but missed the Jacobian/Hessian contraction mechanism for all-n
P6 near miss: had K_n theorem (c=1/3), barrier greedy, leverage reasoning, but stayed in full-spectrum barrier space instead of top-sigma variant
P6 failure mode closely parallels P4: endpoint fixation + object inertia. Same process lesson.
P4's endpoint fixation motivates state-variable hop protocol: when terminal inequality recurs, force new potential/barrier definitions
P6's object inertia confirms the state-variable hop rule mirrors P4 almost verbatim
P6 coaching case study: 15-minute reframing produced K_n proof after 8-hour TryHarder loop. But did NOT produce full general-graph closure.
Cycle methodology produces negative knowledge transfer: each failed cycle generates a structural obstruction theorem
Non-blinded evaluation may inflate 'correct direction' judgments
55-hour iterative protocol is not comparable to single-shot prompts; claims should be 'different protocol, better outcomes'
Human coaching contribution is not isolated from protocol effect; reframing prompts are plausible automation targets
YES bias directly motivates mandatory falsification: spend one full cycle on the opposite answer before committing
Domain-depth gap motivates domain-depth audit: identify specialized-knowledge problems early, allocate extra adversarial testing
P1's false-premise trap is the canonical instance: argument looks correct at every step, only domain knowledge reveals the error
P7's conditional-to-closure gap is a subtler instance: the conditional step's discharge is what deep theory prevents
Domain-depth gap explains why the epistemic weakness is systematic, not accidental
Protocol advantage demonstrates that computational power and iteration help, but don't address the epistemic frontier
The epistemic weakness (false premises invisible to internal checks) defines the frontier: depth of domain knowledge for falsification
Mandatory falsification is the operational response to the frontier thesis
Domain-depth audit is the strategic response to the frontier thesis
State-variable hop protocol addresses the near-miss pattern that prevented full closure on YES problems

stats.argument_flow: D0+D1 -> D2 -> {TA,TB,TC} -> {success,failure} patterns -> {near-misses, epistemic weakness} -> prescriptions + thesis. Threats challenge the strength claims.
